newsitem.title: USA: US swap spreads recoil slightly after recent gains.
newsitem.headline: US swap spreads recoil slightly after recent gains.

text.p: U.S. interest rate swap spreads pulled back slightly on Wednesday after making steady gains in the past few weeks, traders said.
Still, the 10-year area was better bid toward the close as repo rates tightened somewhat, they added.
"Undoubtedly, some people felt like taking profits," a U.S. bank trader in California said of the mild pullback. "It came off highs, but I think the market's pretty comfortable right here."
The 10-year spread, which had traded as wide as 39-1/2 basis points on Tuesday, traded mostly around 38-1/4 today.
The 10-year maturity has gradually widened by about five basis points in the past two weeks or so after the U.S. Treasury scrapped sales of conventional 10-year notes in July and October.
Traders said the rest of the curve was little changed, perhaps with a slight consolidative tone.

A New York bank trader said the Treasury's $11.5 billion five-year note auction today and the $15.5 billion two-year note auction on Tuesday had virtually no impact on swap spreads. Two- and five-year spreads stood at 27/29 bps and 25/28 bps, little changed on the day.

The five-year note auction produced a high yield of 6.298 percent, at which 87 percent of the bids were awarded, with a bid-to-cover ratio at 3.19 times. Tuesday's two-year notes saw a high yield of 6.027 percent, at which 90 percent were awarded, and a bid-to-cover of 2.46 times.
A late slide in the Treasury bond market today had negligible effect on swap rates, traders said.
The California trader said daily fluctuations in government bond yields, which have not been more than several basis points lately, "don't really change the fundamentals of the swaps market."
